# CYBERSPACE AND NON-STATE ACTORS: THE STATE'S INTERNATIONAL OBLIGATION

Valluri Parthasarthi, ICFAI University

## Classification of Cyber conflict

One of the concerns in international humanitarian law is that of the classification of Cyber conflict¹, Classification of conflict is the first step in international humanitarian law as the identification determines legal subjects² which are to be applied to it. It is essential to determine the character of the Cyber conflict, whether international or Non-international in nature. But prior to the inception of Geneva convention, Lassa Oppenheim’s definition of war was well accepted, which stated, “war is a contention between two or more States, through their armed forces, for the purpose of overpowering each other an imposing such conditions of peace as the victor pleases to be”³. The key element in the mentioned definition is that the, conflict must have happened between two States. However the interstate conflict within the State was considered a non-international conflict unless it reaches a certain degree of belligerency. The term ‘belligerency’ and its implications have been discussed in United Kingdom’s ministry’s manual of Law and Armed conflict⁴. After the carnage of the Second World War the international community took a different step in recognizing war in technical and material sense, hence developed into international customary law. Articles 2, 3 which are common for all the four Geneva Conventions there are two certain criteria which can be established to determine the international armed conflict that there is a confrontation between two States and the hostilities shall amount to armed conflict. According to Article 3, the armed conflict is not of an international nature but occurring in the territory of one of the contracting parties. The

International Committee of Red Cross (ICRC) in the year 1949 broadened the scope of international armed conflict by its additional protocol I and II to the Geneva Conventions. The nature of armed conflict and the acts under it which constitute is mentioned under this Article⁵. Geneva conventions and its additional protocols, conflict can be broadly classified into three categories they are:

a. International armed conflict between States.
b. worldwide outfitted clash including national freedom developments⁶.
c. Non-international armed conflict between a State and armed groups or organized armed groups.

The first and third are recognized as customary classifications of conflict.

## International Cyber conflict

It may be noted that for armed conflict there must be armed forces and it shall be international in nature (between States). It has to be further noted that, Cyber attacks are not aggressive and kinetic in nature per se. There are no weapons involved. Therefore at first instance, it can be deduced that Cyber-attacks are not armed in nature, such a deduction shall be dangerous and harmful to the Countries.

According to Article 49 (1) of the Additional Protocol- 1 defines attacks. “as act of violence against the adversary either in attack or defence”. Similarly, the International Criminal Tribunal for former Yugoslavia in the case of Tadiac⁷, said “resorting to armed force between States without recognizing any threshold for the duration or intensity of hostilities”. However, Cyber-attacks are not violent in nature but can trigger vehement circumstances. Hence, the classification of a cyber conflict requires nuanced examination.

The ICRC⁹ has taken a position on Cyber-attacks that, anything which disables an object is also an attack when it does not cause physical damage¹⁰; this is a reasonable motion considering the extension for the notion of damage so is concerned. Since the operation is an attack, it is also armed in terms of qualification for armed conflict. That said, a de minimis standard should attach.

In addition to the attack being ‘armed’ it also has to be ‘international’ in nature. By the term international, it means an act by State or an act attributable by the State in a conflict. # Non-International Cyber Conflict

The concept of Non-International armed conflict has been defined in negative by the common Article 3 in the Geneva conventions. Any violence between State’s armed groups and dissident armed groups within a State can be defined as Non-International armed conflict. The Additional Protocol – II, has also defined Non international armed conflict as a hostility between State’s forces and organized opposing armed forces. Hence, the two ingredients in determining the Non-International armed conflict are (i) participation by an organized armed group and (ii) with a particular level of intensity. According to common Article 3, the groups must be armed and organized for it to be considered as a party in the conflict. The ICTY has defined this element of it in the case of Prosecutor v. Limaj¹⁴, “some degree of organisation by the parties will suffice to establish the existence of an armed conflict. This degree need not be the same as that required for establishing the responsibility of superiors for the acts of their subordinates within the organization, as no determination of individual criminal responsibility is intended under this provision of the Statute”¹⁵. The group shall be organized, the term organized means acting in a cordial manner and capability to engage in violence in mission planning, sharing intelligence and exercising command and control, it is necessary for a group to possess these fundamentals to be considered as a party to the conflict. From the above it is clear that individuals who conduct Cyber-attacks against State cannot meet the organized criteria. Cyber-attacks conducted by a group on online are a bit difficult to classify because the members of the group might not know each other in their operations, however they act in a coordinated manner like setting objectives, identify the weakness in the system, injection of malware and maintain defences, all these activities are performed together in a coordinated manner. One of the other criterion to be met is the group shall be under the responsible command, it is not essential to have a hierarchical order of armed force but if capable of planning and executing operations, then it fall under this definition. In virtual organized group, this criteria can be met because of the nature of the operation carried for which it can be equated to military operations.

In summation to being organized, the group must also be armed. The meaning of armed in the Non-international armed conflict a be parallel comparison can be made to international armed conflict. As discussed above, it generally assumes the conduct of ‘attacks’. Yet, since Non-international armed conflict is ascertained on the activities of a group, as distinct from a State, the question of attribution of an individual member’s conduct to the group as a whole arises.

## Non State Actors and ungoverned spaces

The concept of Non-State Actors and its presence in international law has increased steadily in past few decades. The Non-State actors are endowed with infrastructural, economic and institutional power but do not have any corresponding legal duties. The Non-State actors actions in recent times have amounted to gross violation to human rights and have committed violence to the largest degree possible, the impact of Non-State actors on international scenario has been immense hence the United Nations Security Council in the year 2004 passed resolution 1540, which says, “the States are required to refrain from providing any goods, services to or supporting Non State Actors s which develop, obtain, construct or transfer or use chemical weapons¹⁶.” Historically, the international norms have failed to address the imbalance between legal obligation and duties of the Non-State Actors. The concept of Non-State actors can be understood as an entity, which is not actually a State and usually referred to armed, religious or civil groups. The CONTONOU defines Non State actors on a broader scale as, “The actors of cooperation will include: a: State (local, national and regional), b: Non-State: - Private Sector; - Economic and social partners, including trade union organizations; - Civil society in all its forms according to national characteristics¹⁷”. The Non-State actors do not have any affiliation with the official State authorities nor have any financial/legal framework with reference to the States, they are often treated as new subjects of international law. The international law in recent times have undergone significant changes and attempts being made to reduce the gap between Non-State actors and international law paradigm. As said by Nicolas PM, “Nowadays international law reaches beyond nations, many acts such as certain criminal acts, trade, finance, commercial relationships, environmental issues, human rights and more. Now international law directly touches many individuals”¹⁸. With reference to Cyber-attacks,

## State Obligation

It is an established principle in the international law, that States have inherent responsibility on its part to prevent cross border acts which are prohibited under international law. With reference to current international law, there are particularly four categories of offences which is an Obligation for the States to criminalise, they are offences against confidentiality, integrity and availability of Computer Systems, computer relates offences (Forgery, fraud) and offences related to Copyrights and related rights¹⁹.

As discussed above the presence of Non-State actors in the international arena have been in ascendance, and the alleged acts committed by Non-State actors had caused considerable damage to the aggrieved countries. The States are obligated to obviate their Cyber framework from being exploited in any manner which is harmful to the international legal framework. The obligation consists of having a legal infrastructure domestically to prevent Cyber attacks and to take stringent measures against the offenders and also having a reasonable knowledge or anticipation the threat which might loom from their Cyber set up. The characteristics such as anonymity, accessibility and trans-borderless activities has privileged the Non-State Actors to operate within the States. In a colloquial sense, the States are not responsible for the acts of the

Non-State Actors; mere geographical and territorial link is not enough to hold the State responsible, the State can be held responsible under two circumstances in doing so, the draft Articles on State Responsibility on internationally wrongful Acts has to be considered. The text was adopted in the 53rd Session as submitted to the General Assembly in the year 2001. Article 2 States that, “Elements of an internationally wrongful act of a State

There is an internationally wrongful act of a State when conduct consisting of an action or omission:

(a) is attributable to the State under international law; and

(b) It Constitutes a breach of an international obligation of the State.”

By the above Article the State can be held responsible for the actions of the Non-State Actors if it is an internationally wrongful act which can be attributed to the State. The State must have directed, controlled or instructed the unlawful conduct for it be liable. Therefore, State exercised effective control over the unlawful conduct in question. However, the above doctrine cannot be used widely and is unlikely to occur because, as it is difficult to establish factual link between State and Non-State Actor, the offender must be accurately identified. There are many technical intricacies attached to it, the devices connected to the International Protocol (IP) addresses do not reveal the actual device or offender where offense is committed moreover the use of Virtual Private Networks (VPN) and Botnets have made it difficult to determine the device and address to make this doctrine practically applicable.

## The customary international law

Customary international law refers to international obligations arising from established State practice, as opposed to obligations arising from formal written international treaties. Under customary international law the States are obligated to prevent their territory from being used to cause harm to other countries. This principle was first articulated in the case of Corfu channel²⁰. The brief facts of the case are, two British warships were bombarded by the mines in the Albanian waters, in this instance the State’s responsibility was discussed in maintaining peace and security. The international court of Justice in this case could not establish that the mines were set up by the Albanian Government. The Albanian Government should have known the existence of mines and ought to have warned the ships in the international waters. Thus, it

is well established that there is inherent obligation of the State to prevent its territory being used by Non-State Actors to cause significant damage to other States. The Tallinn Manual, prepared by the group of experts on invitation of NATO Cooperative Cyber Defence of Excellence, In late 2009, they met a global gathering of legitimate researchers and professionals to draft a manual tending to the issue of how to translate universal law with regards to Cyber operations and Cyber conflicts. In that capacity, it was the principal push to analyse this subject thoroughly and definitively and to convey some level of clearness to the related complex legitimate issues. Rule 5 of the Manual states that, State shall not knowingly allow the Cyber infrastructure located in its territory or under its exclusive governmental control to be used for acts that adversely and unlawfully affect other States²¹. This onus also applies to harmful conduct originating from a State's territory. By referring to the Nicaragua Case²², International Court of Justice held that Nicaragua was under an obligation to prevent its territory being used as a trafficking route for military equipment which was exploited by insurgents in El Salvador. Using the same comparison it can be established that in Cyberspace there exists a customary obligation to prevent Trans boundary activities which will affect the States adversely but also to prevent the Non-State Actors from using the Cyber infrastructure from being exploited.

In the Bosnian Genocide case the ICJ held that,

“it is clear that the obligation in question is one of conduct and not one of result, in the sense that a State cannot be under an obligation to succeed, whatever the circumstances, in preventing the commission of genocide: the obligation of States parties is rather to employ all means reasonably available to them, so as to prevent genocide as far as possible.”

In discussing the nature of State’s obligation to prevent a conflict it should be noticed that there is no absolute obligation on State to succeed in quelling the insurgency. There is an obligation of the State to act in due diligence, i.e. For the State to take all necessary actions by reasonable means available to it. Where a State fails to conduct itself reasonably and violates an obligation of conduct the State is liable for the failure to prevent the unlawful conduct and not for the act that produces the resulting harm, which is significant from the perspective of the adequacy of compensation/reparations owed to the victim. commitments of counteractive action are normally interpreted as best endeavours commitments, obliging States to take all sensible or important measures to keep a given occasion from occurring, but without warranting that the occasion won't happen. Professor Pisillo- Mazzeschi in his work on due diligence and the nature of International responsibility of the State has Stated that,

The first is that of possessing, on a permanent basis, a legal and administrative apparatus normally able to guarantee respect for the international norm on prevention. The second obligation, instead, is that of using such apparatus with the diligence that the circumstances require²³”.

It is also important for the State to have a strong legal framework which prohibits and punishes the wrongdoing of Cyber warfare. It is a well-established principle under customary international law that the State is obligated to have legal mechanisms which will not affect the interests of other States adversely. Developing State capability of preventing Cyber-attacks will invariably require enacting legislations and establishment of effective judicial authority to monitor the same. The States shall possess a legal system and sufficient resources to maintain a mechanism to control and monitor the activities. The States with a well developed economy and strong resources with regards to Cyber infrastructure are in a better position to monitor and to have an effective control mechanism in comparison to the States which are not well equipped with technological expertise and resources. However, basic vigilance, employment of law enforcing authorities in the territory of the State which is a basic attributes of a Government are expected from a Statee. International law is not worried with the way in which States choose to meet this specific obligation of theirs, In as much as these laws are sensibly adequate to anticipate antagonistic acts or to rebuff them after they have happened, the State has played out its obligation.

## An Obligation of Conduct

The Convention on Cybercrime, requires States to adopt measures to establish procedures for the purpose of criminal investigations into, and criminal proceedings for, these offences²⁴. The above provision clearly obligates a State to devise a mechanism to curb the offences of Cyber

threats. If a State is having a requisite legal framework, the obligation is to use the framework to address the threats and to reduce its effect. In the conduct of malicious Cyber threats and trans boundary attacks, the convention on Cyber Crime (Council of Europe) requires State parties to adopt legislative and other measures the offences listed in the Convention are punishable by effective means²⁵. There is an obligation of conduct in International Law the standard in which each State is expected to act in furtherance to achieve the objectives of International law. The standard set for care is the due diligence standard, the obligation of due diligence is applied to International environment law, international human right law etc. This Article aims to characterize the material substance of the commitment of due diligence with specific reference to the standard commitment upon States to utilize their ability to keep their Cyber framework from being utilized by Non-State actors as a stage to perform trans boundary Cyber attacks. One of the primary elements of due diligence is the element of knowledge, it is necessary for the State to have knowledge about the threat for it suppress it and take necessary action. In the Corfu case, it was held that, “it cannot be concluded from the mere fact of the control exercised by a State over its territory and waters that that State necessarily knew, or ought to have known what was happening”²⁶. It is to be observed that, because a threat emerged within a State’s territory it does not imply that the State ought to have known about the imminent threat. Referring the Corfu Case, the ICJ indicated that Albania ought to have known the presence of the mines in its coastal waters, which it had control of it, the fact that Albanian coastal forces demanded the foreign vessels to request for permission before they entered the Strait further shifted the liability on Albania. The court presumed that the States shall know about the facts which are which are widely known or can be known through official government channels. The preposition of “State should have known “, plays an important role in international law as it will not be in harmony if a State could avoid responsibility by claiming it of inadequate knowledge if it could have discovered illegal activity through diligent decision. It is true in international scenario if any activity contrary to international law appears to have taken place within the territory of a State may be called upon to give its explication about it but the States cannot elude such a request by citing its ignorance of such activities which happened within the territory of the State. In the context of having adequate knowledge about the circumstances, the immediate question which arises is, “whether it is reasonable to expect the State would have known about the threat in those circumstances?”, in light of Cyber

infrastructure it is reasonable to assert that the State having adequate technical capacity and Cyber Infrastructure to have known about the circumstances. After establishing the circumstances which ought to have been known by the State it also essential to address the due diligence standard require and how much affirmative action can be expected from the State. In a much broader sense the States are obligated to use their legislative framework and infrastructure to check the threats which are originated within the territory and deterring the future wrong doers. In a famous Pulp Mills decision between Uruguay and Argentina the ICJ rules that, “is an obligation which entails not only the adoption of appropriate rules and measures, but also a certain level of vigilance in their enforcement”²⁷. In fulfilling States obligation the States are required to conduct investigation process and effectively reprimand the individuals. This principle was further laid down in the Janes Case²⁸, Mexican authorities failed in their duty of due diligence to protect from harm an American citizen in Mexico because, the Mexican authorities took no proper steps to apprehend and punish Carbajal [the individual responsible for killing the American national] and that such efforts as were made were lax and inadequate. The Tribunal concluded that “[t]he culprit is liable for having killed or murdered an American national; the Government is liable for not having measured up to its duty of diligently prosecuting and properly punishing the offender”.

Hence, as an obligation of conduct, as opposed to come about, deciding how a reasonable State would have responded to a risk is liable to an 'accessible means' examination, which requires recognizable proof of the monetary, specialized and Human Resources of the State. The essence of the matter is that a due diligence commitment must be translated in a way which does not force an outlandish results or impose disproportionate burden on societies. Therefore in order to discharge due diligence obligation to prevent Cyber Attacks or any kind of an act which is contrary to the principle of International law, a State is required only to take those measures that are reasonably available and within its power.

## Conclusion

This essay has discussed that customary international law imposes an obligation on member States to prevent Cyber Infrastructure present in the territory of the State from being used in a manner which causes injury to other States. The obligation includes, the States to have a legal mechanism within the territory which is capable of controlling Cyber Attacks and secondly,

This duty does not specify the nature of legal mechanism that is required by the States to cogently address Cyber threats emerging from Cyber Space. In a heavily interconnected domain like Cyber Space the Non-State Actors will easily reroute their malicious Cyber Operations through the Cyber Infrastructure of a particular State whose technological capability is comparatively less to minimise the possibility of the State to suppress the attacks. For the above reasons, in a challenging domain like Cyber space it is necessary to have closely knit legal framework to curb the menace of malicious Cyber attacks. Devising of a Treaty to regulate how States address threats emerging from Cyber Space. The benefits of Treaty not only include co-operation among States but also by ameliorating States to adopt certain laws which are considered to suppress Cyber threats. With a specific end goal to make a safe the internet what is required is imminent participation and joint effort between the important partners (counting global associations, States, programming suppliers, digital security organizations and so forth) over issues of digital security and Internet administration. The Global Forum for Cyber Expertise (GFCE) established in the year 2015 with 50 members, aims to trade best practices and mastery on digital limit building. The point is to distinguish effective approaches, practices and thoughts and increase these on a worldwide level. Together with accomplices from NGOs, the tech group and the scholarly community GFCE individuals create handy activities to build Cyber capacity. However, it being a soft law mechanism it is necessary to address the issue with related Cyber-Specific Laws and International Treaty which addresses the same.

# Non-International Cyber Conflict
The concept of Non-International armed conflict has been defined in negative by the common Article 3 in the Geneva conventions. Any violence between State’s armed groups and dissident armed groups within a State can be defined as Non-International armed conflict. The Additional Protocol – II, has also defined Non international armed conflict as a hostility between State’s forces and organized opposing armed forces. Hence, the two ingredients in determining the Non-International armed conflict are (i) participation by an organized armed group and (ii) with a particular level of intensity. According to common Article 3, the groups must be armed and organized for it to be considered as a party in the conflict. The ICTY has defined this element of it in the case of Prosecutor v. Limaj, “some degree of organisation by the parties will suffice to establish the existence of an armed conflict. This degree need not be the same as that required for establishing the responsibility of superiors for the acts of their subordinates within the organization, as no determination of individual criminal responsibility is intended under this provision of the Statute”. The group shall be organized, the term organized means acting in a cordial manner and capability to engage in violence in mission planning, sharing intelligence and exercising command and control, it is necessary for a group to possess these fundamentals to be considered as a party to the conflict. From the above it is clear that individuals who conduct Cyber-attacks against State cannot meet the organized criteria. Cyber-attacks conducted by a group on online are a bit difficult to classify because the members of the group might not know each other in their operations, however they act in a coordinated manner like setting objectives, identify the weakness in the system, injection of malware and maintain defences, all these activities are performed together in a coordinated manner. One of the other criterion to be met is the group shall be under the responsible command, it is not essential to have a hierarchical order of armed force but if capable of planning and executing operations, then it fall under this definition. In virtual organized group, this criteria can be met because of the nature of the operation carried for which it can be equated to military operations.
In summation to being organized, the group must also be armed. The meaning of armed in the Non-international armed conflict a be parallel comparison can be made to international armed conflict. As discussed above, it generally assumes the conduct of ‘attacks’. Yet, since Non-international armed conflict is ascertained on the activities of a group, as distinct from a State, the question of attribution of an individual member’s conduct to the group as a whole arises.

## Non State Actors and ungoverned spaces
The concept of Non-State Actors and its presence in international law has increased steadily in past few decades. The Non-State actors are endowed with infrastructural, economic and institutional power but do not have any corresponding legal duties. The Non-State actors actions in recent times have amounted to gross violation to human rights and have committed violence to the largest degree possible, the impact of Non-State actors on international scenario has been immense hence the United Nations Security Council in the year 2004 passed resolution 1540, which says, “the States are required to refrain from providing any goods, services to or supporting Non State Actors s which develop, obtain, construct or transfer or use chemical weapons.” Historically, the international norms have failed to address the imbalance between legal obligation and duties of the Non-State Actors. The concept of Non-State actors can be understood as an entity, which is not actually a State and usually referred to armed, religious or civil groups. The CONTONOU defines Non State actors on a broader scale as, “The actors of cooperation will include: a: State (local, national and regional), b: Non-State: - Private Sector; - Economic and social partners, including trade union organizations; - Civil society in all its forms according to national characteristics”. The Non-State actors do not have any affiliation with the official State authorities nor have any financial/legal framework with reference to the States, they are often treated as new subjects of international law. The international law in recent times have undergone significant changes and attempts being made to reduce the gap between Non-State actors and international law paradigm. ## State Obligation
It is an established principle in the international law, that States have inherent responsibility on its part to prevent cross border acts which are prohibited under international law. With reference to current international law, there are particularly four categories of offences which is an Obligation for the States to criminalise, they are offences against confidentiality, integrity and availability of Computer Systems, computer relates offences (Forgery, fraud) and offences related to Copyrights and related rights.
As discussed above the presence of Non-State actors in the international arena have been in ascendance, and the alleged acts committed by Non-State actors had caused considerable damage to the aggrieved countries. The States are obligated to obviate their Cyber framework from being exploited in any manner which is harmful to the international legal framework. The obligation consists of having a legal infrastructure domestically to prevent Cyber attacks and to take stringent measures against the offenders and also having a reasonable knowledge or anticipation the threat which might loom from their Cyber set up. The characteristics such as anonymity, accessibility and trans-borderless activities has privileged the Non-State Actors to operate within the States. There is an internationally wrongful act of a State when conduct consisting of an action or omission:

## The customary international law
Customary international law refers to international obligations arising from established State practice, as opposed to obligations arising from formal written international treaties. Under customary international law the States are obligated to prevent their territory from being used to cause harm to other countries. This principle was first articulated in the case of Corfu channel. The brief facts of the case are, two British warships were bombarded by the mines in the Albanian waters, in this instance the State’s responsibility was discussed in maintaining peace and security. The international court of Justice in this case could not establish that the mines were set up by the Albanian Government. The Albanian Government should have known the existence of mines and ought to have warned the ships in the international waters. Thus, it

## Classification of Cyber conflict
One of the concerns in international humanitarian law is that of the classification of Cyber conflict, Classification of conflict is the first step in international humanitarian law as the identification determines legal subjects which are to be applied to it. It is essential to determine the character of the Cyber conflict, whether international or Non-international in nature. But prior to the inception of Geneva convention, Lassa Oppenheim’s definition of war was well accepted, which stated, “war is a contention between two or more States, through their armed forces, for the purpose of overpowering each other an imposing such conditions of peace as the victor pleases to be”. The key element in the mentioned definition is that the, conflict must have happened between two States. However the interstate conflict within the State was considered a non-international conflict unless it reaches a certain degree of belligerency. The term ‘belligerency’ and its implications have been discussed in United Kingdom’s ministry’s manual of Law and Armed conflict. After the carnage of the Second World War the international community took a different step in recognizing war in technical and material sense, hence developed into international customary law. The concept of Non-International armed conflict has been defined in negative by the common Article 3 in the Geneva conventions. Any violence between State’s armed groups and dissident armed groups within a State can be defined as Non-International armed conflict. Hence, the two ingredients in determining the Non-International armed conflict are (i) participation by an organized armed group and (ii) with a particular level of intensity. ## Non State Actors and ungoverned spaces The concept of Non-State Actors and its presence in international law has increased steadily in past few decades. The Non-State actors are endowed with infrastructural, economic and institutional power but do not have any corresponding legal duties. The Non-State actors actions in recent times have amounted to gross violation to human rights and have committed violence to the largest degree possible, the impact of Non-State actors on international scenario has been immense hence the United Nations Security Council in the year 2004 passed resolution 1540, which says, “the States are required to refrain from providing any goods, services to or supporting Non State Actors s which develop, obtain, construct or transfer or use chemical weapons¹⁶.” Historically, the international norms have failed to address the imbalance between legal obligation and duties of the Non-State Actors. The concept of Non-State actors can be understood as an entity, which is not actually a State and usually referred to armed, religious or civil groups. With reference to current international law, there are particularly four categories of offences which is an Obligation for the States to criminalise, they are offences against confidentiality, integrity and availability of Computer Systems, computer relates offences (Forgery, fraud) and offences related to Copyrights and related rights¹⁹.

The States are obligated to obviate their Cyber framework from being exploited in any manner which is harmful to the international legal framework. The obligation consists of having a legal infrastructure domestically to prevent Cyber attacks and to take stringent measures against the offenders and also having a reasonable knowledge or anticipation the threat which might loom from their Cyber set up. ## The customary international law Customary international law refers to international obligations arising from established State practice, as opposed to obligations arising from formal written international treaties. Under customary international law the States are obligated to prevent their territory from being used to cause harm to other countries. This principle was first articulated in the case of Corfu channel²⁰. The brief facts of the case are, two British warships were bombarded by the mines in the Albanian waters, in this instance the State’s responsibility was discussed in maintaining peace and security. The standard set for care is the due diligence standard, the obligation of due diligence is applied to International environment law, international human right law etc. This Article aims to characterize the material substance of the commitment of due diligence with specific reference to the standard commitment upon States to utilize their ability to keep their Cyber framework from being utilized by Non-State actors as a stage to perform trans boundary Cyber attacks. One of the primary elements of due diligence is the element of knowledge, it is necessary for the State to have knowledge about the threat for it suppress it and take necessary action. In the Corfu case, it was held that, “it cannot be concluded from the mere fact of the control exercised by a State over its territory and waters that that State necessarily knew, or ought to have known what was happening”²⁶. It is to be observed that, because a threat emerged within a State’s territory it does not imply that the State ought to have known about the imminent threat. Referring the Corfu Case, the ICJ indicated that Albania ought to have known the presence of the mines in its coastal waters, which it had control of it, the fact that Albanian coastal forces demanded the foreign vessels to request for permission before they entered the Strait further shifted the liability on Albania. The court presumed that the States shall know about the facts which are which are widely known or can be known through official government channels. The preposition of “State should have known “, plays an important role in international law as it will not be in harmony if a State could avoid responsibility by claiming it of inadequate knowledge if it could have discovered illegal activity through diligent decision. It is true in international scenario if any activity contrary to international law appears to have taken place within the territory of a State may be called upon to give its explication about it but the States cannot elude such a request by citing its ignorance of such activities which happened within the territory of the State. In a much broader sense the States are obligated to use their legislative framework and infrastructure to check the threats which are originated within the territory and deterring the future wrong doers. This principle was further laid down in the Janes Case²⁸, Mexican authorities failed in their duty of due diligence to protect from harm an American citizen in Mexico because, the Mexican authorities took no proper steps to apprehend and punish Carbajal [the individual responsible for killing the American national] and that such efforts as were made were lax and inadequate. Hence, as an obligation of conduct, as opposed to come about, deciding how a reasonable State would have responded to a risk is liable to an 'accessible means' examination, which requires recognizable proof of the monetary, specialized and Human Resources of the State. The essence of the matter is that a due diligence commitment must be translated in a way which does not force an outlandish results or impose disproportionate burden on societies. Therefore in order to discharge due diligence obligation to prevent Cyber Attacks or any kind of an act which is contrary to the principle of International law, a State is required only to take those measures that are reasonably available and within its power.
